terms.definition: Technical documentation that describes how to use and integrate with an Application Programming Interface, including endpoints, parameters, and code examples.
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a provider and accessed via the internet.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to revert to previous versions and track revision history.
What You See Is What You Get - an editor that allows users to see how content will appear in its final form while editing.
terms.expanded: What You See Is What You Get

terms.definition: JSON Web Token - a secure method for transmitting information between parties as a digitally signed token used for authentication.
A lightweight markup language that uses plain text formatting syntax to create structured documents that can be converted to HTML.
A security system that defines what actions different types of users can perform and what content they can access within a platform.
Documentation designed to allow users to find answers and solve problems independently without contacting support.
Software whose source code is freely available for anyone to view, modify, and distribute under specific licensing terms.
Customer Relationship Management - software systems used to manage interactions and relationships with customers and prospects.
Service Level Agreement - a contract that defines the expected level of service, including uptime guarantees and response times.
The ability for multiple users to work on the same document simultaneously, seeing each other's changes as they happen.
A storage location for code and documentation managed by Git version control system, commonly used for tracking changes in software projects.
The practice of creating clear, concise documentation that explains complex technical information to specific audiences.
